namepart.name: Verified good dump
namepart.description: Verified good dump. Thank God for these!

namepart.name: OverDump
namepart.description: An overdumped ROM image has more data than is actually in the cart. The extra information means nothing and is removed from the true image.

namepart.name: Alternative version
namepart.description: This is simply an alternate version of a ROM. Many games have been re-released to fix bugs or even to eliminate Game Genie codes (Yes, Nintendo hates that device).

namepart.name: Bad Dump
namepart.description: A bad dump often occurs with an older game or a faulty dumper (bad connection). Another common source of [b] ROMs is a corrupted upload to a release FTP.

namepart.name: Fixed
namepart.description: A fixed game has been altered in some way so that it will run better on a copier or emulator.

namepart.name: Hack
namepart.description: Something in this ROM is not quite as it should be. Often a hacked ROM simply has a changed header or has been enabled to run in different regions. Other times it could be a release group intro, or just some kind of cheating or funny hack.

namepart.name: Trained
namepart.description: A trainer is special code which executes before the game is begun. It allows you to access cheats from a menu.

namepart.name: Bung Fix
namepart.description: Bung released a programmable cartridge compatable with the GameBoy which could hold any data you wished to play. However, many games do not function on Bung v1.0 carts and have to be 'fixed.'

namepart.name: BS ROMs
namepart.description: These Japanese ROMs were distributed through a satellite system in Japan known as the Broadcast Satellaview. They were transmitted along with a TV show which was connected to the game in some way. These games were only playable during the show, and thus stop after an hour, and many were timed so that only certain time periods were playable.

namepart.name: Sufami Turbo
namepart.description: The Sufami Turbo device allowed two GameBoy sized carts to be plugged into the SNES. Certain carts combined into new games much like the Sonic and Knuckles lock-on technology by Sega.

namepart.name: Nintendo Power
namepart.description: Nintendo Power has been known to release games only available to its subscribers. Most of these ROMs are Japanese, as this practice occured mainly in Japan.

namepart.name: Japan
namepart.description: Carts with this code will run on both Japanese and Korean machines.

namepart.name: USA
namepart.description: While this code is technically the same as a (U) code, it is a newer header format and represents that the cart will run on USA and Brazil NTSC machines.

namepart.name: non USA
namepart.description: This country code indicates that the cart will run on any non US machine.

namepart.name: Checksum
namepart.description: This code represents a cart with known faulty checksum routines.

namepart.name: PlayChoice 10
namepart.description: The PlayChoice 10 was an arcade unit which played exact copies of NES games in an arcade cabinet. The machines had a choice of 10 games to choose from and ran for about 3 minutes on 25 cents.

namepart.name: Versus
namepart.description: The Versus system ran on similar hardware to the PC10 machines, but simply allowed you to play against each other.
